verb.description: (of troops) come together again in order to continue fighting after a defeat or dispersion.
examples: De Montfort's troops rallied and drove back the king's infantry

verb.description: Recover or cause to recover in health, spirits, or poise.
examples: she floundered for a moment, then rallied again
they rallied her with a drink
synonyms: take a turn for the better
be given a new lease of life
take on a new lease of life

noun.description: A mass meeting of people making a political protest or showing support for a cause.
examples: a rally attended by around 100,000 people

noun.description: A competition for motor vehicles in which they are driven a long distance over public roads or rough terrain, typically in stages and through checkpoints.
A quick or marked recovery after a reverse or a period of weakness.
examples: the market staged a late rally

noun.description: (in tennis and other racket sports) an extended exchange of strokes between players.

origin: Mid 17th century: from French railler to rib, tease (see rail).
